metadata.title: Global genetic patterns reveal host tropism versus cross-taxon transmission of bat 1 Betacoronaviruses 2 3

abstract.text: Emerging infectious diseases due to coronavirus (CoV) infections have received significant global 18 attention in the past decade and have been linked to bats as the original source. The diversity, distribution, 19 and host associations of bat CoVs were investigated to assess their potential for zoonotic transmission.

Phylogenetic, network, and principal coordinate analysis confirmed the classification of betacoronaviruses 21 (BetaCoVs) into five groups (2A to 2E) and a potentially novel group, with further division of 2D into five 22 subgroups. The genetic co-clustering of BetaCoVs among closely related bats reflects host taxon-23 specificity with each bat family as the host for a specific BetaCoV group, potentially a natural barrier 24 against random transmission. The divergent pathway of BetaCoV and host evolution suggests that the 25 viruses were introduced just prior to bat dispersal and speciation. As such, deviant patterns were 26 observed such as for 2D-IV, wherein cross-taxon transmission due to overlap in bat habitats and 27 geographic range among genetically divergent African bat hosts could have played a strong role on their 28 shared CoV lineages. In fact, a few bat taxa especially the subfamily Pteropodinae were shown to host 29 diverse groups of BetaCoVs. Therefore, ecological imbalances that disturb bat distribution may lead to 30 loss of host specificity through cross-taxon transmission and multi-CoV infection. Hence, initiatives that 31 minimize the destruction of wildlife habitats and limit wildlife-livestock-human interfaces are encouraged to 32 help maintain the natural state of bat BetaCoVs in the wild. 33 34 35 36 Importance 37 Bat Betacoronaviruses (BetaCoVs) pose a significant threat to global public health and have been 38 implicated in several epidemics such as the recent pandemic by severe acute respiratory syndrome 39 coronavirus 2. Here, we show that bat BetaCoVs are predominantly host-specific, which could be a 40 natural barrier against infection of other host types. However, a strong overlap in bat habitat and 41 geographic range may facilitate viral transmission to unrelated hosts, and a few bat families have already 42 been shown to host multi-CoV variants. We predict that continued disturbances on the ecological balance 43 may eventually lead to loss of host specificity. When combined with enhanced wildlife-livestock-human 44 interfaces, spillover to humans may be further facilitated. We should therefore start to define the 45 ecological mechanisms surrounding zoonotic events. Global surveillance should be expanded and 46 strengthened to assess the complete picture of bat coronavirus diversity and distribution and their 47 potential to cause spillover infections. 48 49 7).

60 Coronaviruses (CoVs) are pleiomorphic, single-stranded positive-sense RNA viruses with three 61 major structural proteins; a nucleocapsid protein (N) which functions in encapsidating genomic RNA and 62 facilitating its incorporation into virions, a small integral membrane protein (M) with intrinsic membrane-63 bending properties that plays a central role in viral assembly, an envelope glycoprotein (E), and a large 64 spike protein (S) which functions in viral entry and pathogenesis (8-11). CoVs are considered to have the 65 largest genome among RNA viruses at approximately 27 to 30 kb (6). There are four genera by which 66 CoVs are classified, namely Alphacoronaviruses, Betacoronaviruses, Gammacoronaviruses and 67 Deltacoronaviruses (12). Betacoronaviruses (BetaCoVs) are of particular importance as the SARS-CoV, 68 MERS-CoV, and SARS-CoV2 which have caused global epidemics belong to this lineage (5).

69 Betacoronaviruses (BetaCoVs) are further classified into subgenera Embecovirus (also lineage 2A and 70 includes Murine CoV and ChRCoV HKU24), Sarbecovirus (lineage 2B and includes SARS-related CoVs), 71 Merbecovirus (lineage 2C and includes Ty-BatCoV HKU4, Pi-BatCoV HKU5, Hp-BatCoV HKU25, and 72 MERS-related CoVs), Nobecovirus (lineage 2D and includes Ro-BatCoV HKU9 and Ro-BatCoV 73 GCCDC1), and Hibecovirus (lineage 2E and includes Bat Hp-betaCoV Zhejiang2013) (13).

74 HCoV-229E and HCoV-OC43, both human coronaviruses (HCoVs), were first discovered in 75 patients with mild respiratory illness (14). Two new species of HCoVs, the HCoV-NL63 and HCoV-HKU1 76 were also discovered in 2004 and 2005, respectively (15). Disease types caused by HCoVs usually range 77 from gastrointestinal infections, upper respiratory infections, and lower respiratory infections such as 78 pneumonia (16). Further studies revealed that CoVs cause respiratory, enteric, hepatic and neurological 79 diseases in animals like bats, birds, cats, dogs, pigs, mice, horses, and whales (17). Moreover, the 80 SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV which have clear zoonotic origins have also been found to cause lower 81 respiratory infections such as pneumonia. In particular, SARS-CoV has been associated with diffuse 82 alveolar damage (DAD) and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), while MERS-CoV has been 83 linked to renal failure (16). Recently, SARS-CoV2 has been reported to cause pneumonia, ARDS and 84 multiple organ failure (7,18). CoVs can be transmitted via fecal-oral route, respiratory, as well as contact 85 transmission (19). The spread of SARS-CoV has been primarily attributed to human-human transmission via direct contact with respiratory droplets and exposure to fomites (20). Similarly, although no evidence 87 of being sustained, human-human transmission has also been reported for MERS-CoV infections (21). 88 The World Health Organization (WHO) released guidelines on how to limit human-human transmission, 89 and reduce the risk of animal-human transmission in order to contain the rapidly spreading COVID-19 90 disease that started in Wuhan, China (22).

91 There is increasing evidence for the role of bats as hosts of emerging pathogens, specifically 92 viruses (23). Bats (Order: Chiroptera) are one of the most diverse and widely distributed animals, second 93 only to rodents as the most speciose order in class Mammalia (24). They are classified into two suborders, 94 Yinpterochiroptera, which include the false vampire bats (Megadermatidae), horseshoe bats 95 (Rhinolophidae), and megabats or fruit bats (Pteropodidae); and Yangochiroptera which includes vesper 96 bats (Vespertilionidae), sac-winged bats (Emballonuridae) and bulldog bats (Noctilionidae) (25). A 97 significant number of CoVs can be found in bats, thus future spill-over events presents a constant threat 98 to global health (26). In particular, emerging human coronaviruses have been linked to bat sources. 99 Although camels were the source of the MERS-CoV in the Middle East, a coronavirus with 100% nt 100 identity to that of human β-CoV 2c EMC/2012 isolated from a case-patient has been found in bats at a 101 detection rate of 3.5% (27). SARS-like coronaviruses with 92% identity to that of human SARS-CoV 102 isolates have also been detected in horseshoe bats in China. Three species of horseshoe bats from 103 China namely Rhinolophus pearsoni, R. pussilus and R. macrotis demonstrated 28%, 33% and 78%

104 SARS-CoV seroprevalence, respectively (28). Furthermore, SARS-CoV2 was found to be 96% identical 105 to a bat coronavirus at the whole genome level (29). Bat CoVs (BtCoVs) comprise only 6% of the current 106 CoV database although roughly 3,000 genetic lineages of BtCoVs are believed to circulate worldwide (30).

It has also been suggested that future CoV outbreaks can be geographically predicted based on the 108 specific bat species distribution (12). These highlight the need to expand our knowledge on BtCoVs, 109 particularly on their diversity, distribution, host association, and evolution to understand their potential for 110 zoonotic transmission. In this study, these parameters were assessed by classifying representative and 111 unresolved BetaCoVs based on network and phylogenetic analysis of their RNA-dependent RNA 112 polymerase sequences and evaluating patterns of geographic and host distribution. The analysis 113 validated the current classification scheme of BetaCoVs with potentially novel groupings and 114 subgroupings identified. Comparative phylogenetics demonstrated a strong tendency towards host 115 specificity of bat BetaCoVs although there was poor evidence of co-evolution with their hosts.

Although bat BetaCoVs are host taxon-specific, their evolutionary pathways are different from evolution with its host. Instead, this is indicative that the currently circulating viruses may have been introduced relatively recently, i.e. to the most recent common ancestors of each bat taxon but prior to 283 global dispersion and speciation, during which the virus acquired adaptation to its host. The recent 284 introduction of BetaCoVs in bats implies that other factors may have had the opportunity to influence 285 virus-host dynamics. In the succeeding discussions, we will present two deviant phenomena that 286 exemplify this: cross-taxon transmission of CoVs and bat hosts with multi-CoV lineages.

The major clades inferred from 235 the generated Bayesian phylogenetic tree using partial RdRp sequences was consistent with previously 236 reported classification of BetaCoVs (2A or Embecoviruses, 2B or Sarbecoviruses, 2C or Merbecoviruses, 237 2D or Nobecoviruses, and 2E or Hibecoviruses) using whole genome sequences of representative strains 238 (12) and was able to position formerly unclassified bat CoVs. A new clade of unclassified bat BetaCoVs 239 that is genetically distinct from the currently recognized groups was also observed. This classification can 240 correct the GenBank annotation of deviant samples such as the BetaCoVs that grouped with AlphaCoVs, 241 and add information on the currently unclassified BetaCoVs in GenBank. This is also the first report on 242 the comprehensive classification of Nobecoviruses, of which there are currently only two recognized 243 groups: Ro-BtCoV HKU9 and Ro-BtCoV GCCDC1 (12). Our analysis of unclassified BetaCoVs suggests 244 that Nobecovirus diversity may have been underestimated in previous reports. We therefore propose the 245 subclassification of Nobecoviruses into five subgroups (2D-I to 2D-V), which can help update surveillance 246 records and facilitate monitoring of CoV populations in the wild.

FIGREF6.text: The congruent association between the genetic clustering of bat CoVs and their bat hosts at 248 different taxonomic levels (family, subfamily, and genus) and regardless of location suggests bat taxon-249 specific BetaCoV lineages: horseshoe and Old World leaf-nosed bats for 2B Sarbecoviruses, vesper bats 250 for 2C Merbecoviruses, fruit bats for 2D Nobecoviruses, and the closely related American leafed and 251 mustached bats for the new BetaCoV clade. Similar trends were observed upon further analysis of the the single representative Old World leaf-nosed bat for 2E Hibecovirus. These findings support previous 255 reports (31) which we have expanded here to identify the specific bat taxon associated with each 256 BetaCoV group and a more extensive analysis of fruit bat CoVs. Network analysis showed no clear trends 257 in the geographical distribution of closely related BetaCoVs except for 2D-IV, which is composed of four 258 genetically distinct bat hosts (family Pteropodidae subfamily Pteropodinae, Epomophorinae, and 259 Rousettinae; and family Hipposideridae), but all of which are found in Africa. Hence, host specificity could 260 play a major role in BetaCoV diversity, except for 2D-IV for which geography may have a stronger 261 influence.262Host specificity is uncommon in other bat-infecting viruses such as Paramyxoviruses and 263 Papillomaviruses, which have been reported to have prevalent host switches (32,33). Indeed, bats have a 264 predominant viral sharing network, suggesting that cross-species transmission events are common (34).

Various lines of evidence have indicated bat-specific infectivity of CoVs. In one study, BtCoVs from 268 primary infection of C. brachyotis had a reduced level of replication when experimentally inoculated to 269 Rousettus leschenaultii (35). Similarly, the SARS-like WIV1-CoV, which was isolated from Rhinolophus 270 sinicus bats and demonstrated positive replication in R. sinicus cell lines, showed weak infection in 271 Rousettus sp. bats and cell lines (36-38). Indeed, our analysis showed that BetaCoVs from Rousettus sp. 272 (2D-I, 2D-III or 2D-IV) are genetically distinct from Cynopterus sp. (2D-II) or Rhinolophus sp. (2B).

FIGREF8.text: Analysis of bat SARS-like CoV proteins demonstrated the absence of any selective pressure for evolution 274 (39), suggesting that bat CoVs have already reached optimal fitness in their host. Factors that limit 275 transmission to a different host taxon include cell surface receptors, the immune response, and 276 replication fitness (40). These factors may serve as important natural barriers in the transmission of bat 277 BetaCoVs, which can advantageously limit host jumping and co-infection, which otherwise may generate 278 new virus strains with the ability to switch animal hosts (41,42).

Another example is the Pteropodinae bat Dobsonia moluccensis, Dyacopterus spadiceus, and 292 M. minimus that carried Nobecoviruses from various subgroups. Dobsonia sp. and Rousettinae bats are293 primarily cave dwellers that have been documented to co-roost in the same cave habitat (45-49), which 294 could explain their shared BetaCoVs from lineage 2D-I . Evidence of forage site overlap has also been 295 documented for Cynopterus sp. and other Pteropodinae bats such as M. minimus which also feeds on 296 banana and palm trees, and Dyacopterus spadiceus which have been documented to feed together with 297 Cynopterus horsfieldii in the same foliage site (45). Here, we reported that these Cynopterinae and 298 Pteropodinae bats have BetaCoVs that commonly belong to 2D-II. A final example is 2D-IV, which is 299 composed of four genetically distinct bat hosts from Epomophorinae, Pteropodinae (E. helvum), 300 Rousettinae (R. aegyptiacus), and Hipposidiridae/Old World leaf-nosed bats (T. persicus). The diverse 301 hosts of 2D-IV could be explained by overlaps in foraging, roosting, and distribution of African bats. FIGREF11.text: The phylogenetic analysis in this study points to bats as potential origins of other mammalian324 CoVs (2A). Switching to another taxon would require specific genetic alterations that will facilitate 325 infection of a different host species (40). This entails a strong selection pressure, and all the more when 326 switching to other animal hosts (35-38). A good demonstration of this is the evolution of human SARS-327 CoV which is believed to have occurred in a stepwise fashion, with the spike protein undergoing early 328 selective pressure probably to mediate the switch from animal to human hosts, followed by the RdRp in 329 the late stages to facilitate a more efficient replication in humans (42). Furthermore, the human MERS-330 CoV EMC/2012 was found to replicate in Artibeus jamaicensis bats, as well as in various cell lines from 331 different bat families that have never been reported to host MERS-CoV strains (37,57). Viral strains with 332 broad-spectrum tropism such as human SARS and MERS CoV are the result of an evolutionarily 333 acquired ability that combined the use of new receptors, host immune evasion, and efficient replication in

Furthermore, the recent SARS-CoV2 outbreak in China has been reported to originate from 342 a seafood market in Wuhan with exposure to wild animals (62). It is therefore 354 recommended to explore the incidence of CoVs in the wild population of C. brachyotis in the Philippines, 355 which may present a higher risk for future spillover infection in animal and/or human populations due to 356 their presence in urban communities. CoVs from subfamilies Cynopterinae (Cynopterus sp., Dyacopterus spadiceus, subclade 2D-II, with the genus Cynopterus (83%) as the predominantly sampled group. 2D-IV was 185 composed of CoVs mostly sampled from the African bat Eidolon helvum (subfamily Pteropodinae) (32%), and the rest from other African fruit bats of subfamily Epomophorinae (Micropteropus pusillus, Epomophorus sp., Epomops franqueti, Megaloglossus woermanni, and Mynonycteris angolensis), subfamily Rousettinae (R. aegyptiacus), and family Hipposidiridae (Triaenops persicus). Subclade 2D-V 189 was composed solely of CoVs from Pteropus sp., commonly known as flying foxes (subfamily Pteropodinae), while the sole BtCoV representative in clade 2E has been detected in Hipposideros pratti 191 (family Hipposidiridae). Finally, the unresolved clade was composed of American leafed (family Phyllostomidae) and mustached (family Mormoopidae) bat hosts. Comparative phylogenetics of BetaCoVs and their bat hosts divided accordingly into Macroglossini, Pteropodinae, Cynopterinae, Rousettinae, and Epomophorinae lineages, except for E. helvum which was separated from the Pteropodinae group. In general, there was a genetic clustering of bat hosts found within BetaCoV lineages. The 2B BetaCoVs was comprised of horseshoe and Old World leaf-nosed bat hosts that shared a common 204 ancestor. A similar pattern was observed for 2C and the 2D subgroups. The 2C BetaCoVs was composed of vesper bat hosts, 2D-I/2D-III of Rousettinae bat hosts, 2D-II of Cynopterinae bat hosts, and 2D-IV of Epomophorinae bat hosts, wherein each bat group also formed their corresponding genetic clade. The 2D-V subgroup was composed of solely Pteropus sp. which belongs to Pteropodinae. Finally, the 208 unresolved CoV clade was represented by American leafed and mustached microbat hosts (P. davyii and 209 A. lituratus) that clustered with a common ancestor. Meanwhile, 2E was represented by only one bat host: Hipposideros sp. of the Old World leaf nosed bats.
